Author: dimxy#2587
Content: (Maybe when JL reads this he would suggest a better idea)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just do a test with funds in all segids to smooth out the granularity of initial blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: statistically if staking is N times more, over time, it should end up with N times more

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to make it easier to detect, best to make it 30x for testing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: put funds in 64 different segids for each category, just do it with a script

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in normal use it wont matter

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: So we want to do a test with activated coins split into 64 segids.

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
Suppose we have  those 64 addresses, with some utxos on them, forever.
And we will not split locked-in-loop amounts into segids.
Wouldn't these activated utxos outperform locked-in-loop utxos (that are not split)?
(As I understand splitting is needed only for initial blocks. So later it does not matter, does it?)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with many users, the splitting effect is averaged out

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but active users can get more blocks by analyzing the 64 segids and putting coins in the weakest one

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a multiplayer game on 64 segids, with limited resources

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: very complex strategy game that depends on how everybody else allocates their coins

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe there is a simple bug in the boosting calc?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you know for mining to make it easier you need to multiple the value

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
Actually I did a test for only activated coins on 2 PoS nodes. I wanted to get to the point where both equal staking utxos would generate approximately equal results.
But my chain for a weekly test duration was in unstable state (apparently because of no staking utxo spliting).
So I wondered once more if the splitting needs only for initial blocks or it is better to have it always

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: Yes, I 'll do splitting and provide the chain to be stable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you start with them split, then each one will increase the coins in that segid, overtime relatively balanced. which is fine

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: number of nodes is not what matters as a single node can stake many addresses

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
You wrote `put funds in 64 different segids for each category'.
If we have 'activated' and 'lock-in-loop' accounts does this mean we need to split both of them?
(our current locked-in-loop account implementation does not allow splitting because of shared 1of2 address)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: need to make 64 different loops?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it could be there is a bug in your staking percentage multiplier. can you post the code that does the calculation

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
I mean suppose we have a credit loop. The issuer has locked some amount in this loop.
This amount should have 3x multiplier in staking.
The question is should this amount be split on 64 segids?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as long as it really has 3x the chance, that is what matters

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think there must be some bug in the 3x calc

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how exactly do you make it 3x

Author: dimxy#2587
dimxy#2587
Content: MarmaraGetStakeMultiplier() returns either 1 or 3:

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and you verified that the actual stake compare uses the bigger value?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: lets try a 100x boost, that should make it very clear and not need to fiddle with segids

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
No, I have not reached this testing progress yet.
I have been testing only how activated staking amounts work which always should have 1x multiplier. (and I had my chain unstable, as Alright yesterday explained it could have been because of lack of segids)

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: So I initiated this discussion about what should we do about splitting utxos on segids in marmara chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you need to make sure the actual staking calc is using the bigger values

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: okay let's try 100x or similar value
